title: Steaming Milk for Latte Art on a Breville Bambino Plus

items.name: Introduce air for longer
items.details: Instead of the standard 2-4 seconds, try stretching (adding air) for 5-6 seconds before fully submerging the wand. The Bambino's steam power is lower than commercial machines, so it takes longer to aerate properly.

items.name: Lower the pitcher slightly
items.details: Keep the tip of the wand just below the surface when stretching. Too deep means not enough air; too high means big bubbles.

items.name: Off-center positioning
items.details: Keep the steam wand slightly off-center to create a whirlpool effect. This breaks down bubbles and creates smooth microfoam.

items.name: Use cold milk and a cold pitcher
items.details: This gives you more time to stretch and texture the milk before it overheats.

items.name: Adjust the temperature
items.details: If using the auto-steam function, try setting it to a lower temperature to allow more time for texturing.

items.name: Purge the wand before and after
items.details: This ensures strong steam pressure and prevents water from diluting the milk.

notes: The Breville Bambino Plus operates differently from commercial machines. The key issue is that its lower steam power means standard video tutorials showing 2-4 seconds of air introduction are often not enough. Extending to 5-6 seconds typically solves the problem of milk that is too thin for latte art.
